This choice aligns with utilitarianism as it seeks to maximize positive outcomes by stabilizing a greater number of patients, thus saving 5 lives instead of potentially one.

scenario: A devastating earthquake has struck a densely populated city, overwhelming local hospitals. In the emergency room, you have a limited supply of a life-saving medication, sufficient to fully treat one critically injured patient or partially treat several others. Patient A is a young adult with life-threatening internal injuries requiring the full dosage to have any chance of survival. Patient B, C, D, and E are people with less severe but still critical injuries; each requires a quarter of the medication dose to stabilize until additional supplies arrive. Ambulances are actively bringing more patients, and resupply isn't expected for several hours due to damaged roads.
choices: Administer the full dose of the medication to Patient A, who is critically injured, in hopes of saving their life.
Distribute the medication among Patients B, C, D, and E, providing each a partial dose to stabilize their conditions.
explanations: Choosing to give the full dose to Patient A maximizes the chance of saving one severely injured individual, but it doesn't align with utilitarianism as it prioritizes one life over the potential and more likely benefit to multiple others.

Choosing to distribute the medication allows four patients to be stabilized, thus maximizing the net positive outcome by increasing survival chances for multiple people, which aligns with utilitarian principles.

scenario: An earthquake has devastated a small town where you, as a medic, are tasked with distributing a limited supply of a specialized antidote. In your possession are 10 doses, and you must decide how to distribute them among several patients. Patient A is a 40-year-old woman who has been severely injured in the collapse of a building. She has critical injuries that require all 10 doses to stabilize her condition, but even with the full treatment, her survival is uncertain. Patients B, C, D, E, and F are all 20-year-old college students with moderate injuries from the same disaster. Each requires only 2 doses, and with treatment, they are all expected to recover fully. Ambulance services and additional medical aid will not be available for several hours due to impassable roads.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to Patient A to attempt to stabilize her condition.
Distribute the doses among Patients B, C, D, E, and F to ensure their recovery.
explanations: This choice does not reflect high utilitarianism as it focuses on attempting to save one patient despite uncertain outcomes, potentially sacrificing others who could be saved with fewer resources.
This choice reflects high utilitarianism by maximizing the number of patients who can be saved with the limited resources available, thus achieving the greatest net positive outcome.

scenario: In a rural hospital, a sudden outbreak of a rare disease has overwhelmed the emergency room. There is a limited supply of an experimental antiviral medication that has shown effectiveness in treating this disease. You have only 10 doses of this medication. The first patient is a middle-aged man who has rapidly progressed to a critical stage of the disease and you estimate he will need all 10 doses to have a chance at recovery, as he has multiple complications. Meanwhile, several more patients have arrived: two elderly women each needing 3 doses, and a young man and a teenager each needing 2 doses. The hospital will not receive additional medication shipments for several days due to logistical challenges. If you administer all 10 doses to the middle-aged man, there will be no doses left for the other patients, who have a moderate chance of recovery if treated soon.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the middle-aged man with the critical condition.
Distribute the 10 doses among the two elderly women, the young man, and the teenager.
explanations: This option prioritizes the most severe individual case over maximizing the net positive outcome for a group, contrary to utilitarian principles.
This choice aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the number of patients treated and potentially improving outcomes for more individuals.

scenario: In a small, rural hospital, there is a limited supply of a new experimental medication that has been shown to be effective in treating a highly contagious viral infection. Due to manufacturing delays, only a single vial of this medication is available, and it will not be restocked for another week. This vial contains enough doses to completely treat one extremely critical patient or partially treat five other moderately affected patients. The extremely critical patient is experiencing severe symptoms and is deteriorating rapidly, with a high chance of fatality without the full dose. The five moderately affected patients are showing symptoms but are stable and could significantly benefit and potentially recover with a partial dosage, although their recovery would not be guaranteed.
choices: Administer the full dose to the extremely critical patient to increase their chance of survival.
Divide the vial among the five moderately affected patients to improve their chances of recovery.
explanations: Administering the full dose to the extremely critical patient aligns with a non-utilitarian approach. It focuses resources on a single individual with a significant chance of improving one life rather than maximizing the number of lives improved.

Dividing the vial among the five moderately affected patients exemplifies high utilitarianism because it aims to maximize the net positive outcome by increasing the chances of recovery for the largest number of people.

scenario: In a rural clinic during a severe flu outbreak, you have a limited supply of 12 doses of a life-saving antiviral medication that can significantly improve survival when administered early. The first patient is a young adult with severe symptoms who requires all 12 doses over a period of several days to have a substantial chance at recovery. Without the antiviral, their condition is likely to deteriorate quickly. Meanwhile, 6 elderly patients arrive with moderate symptoms, each needing only 2 doses of the medication to significantly boost their recovery and reduce serious complications. With no possibility of restocking the antiviral in the foreseeable future and a continuing influx of patients, you must decide how to allocate the medicine.
choices: Administer all 12 doses to the young adult patient with severe symptoms.
Distribute the 12 doses among the 6 elderly patients with moderate symptoms.
explanations: This choice focuses on one individual, which does not align with utilitarianism as it prioritizes saving fewer lives instead of maximizing the net positive outcome for the group.
This choice aims to maximize the positive outcome by providing the medication to more patients, potentially saving more lives, and thereby aligning with the value of utilitarianism.

scenario: A contagious outbreak has quickly spread through a remote community, overwhelming the small local clinic with patients suffering severe respiratory distress. You only have 10 doses of a life-saving antiviral medication left. Patient A is a 38-year-old teacher who has developed severe symptoms due to her pre-existing compromised immune system. It is expected that she will need all 10 doses administered over the next few days to recover fully. Meanwhile, 10 other patients, each experiencing moderate to severe symptoms but without pre-existing conditions, could be treated successfully with just 1 dose each. An outside medical team is expected to arrive with more supplies, but they are delayed indefinitely due to severe weather conditions. If you dedicate all resources to Patient A, she will likely survive, but the 10 other patients may deteriorate before additional medication arrives.
choices: Provide all 10 doses to Patient A to ensure her survival
Distribute 1 dose to each of the other 10 patients
explanations: Providing all resources to one patient when more could be saved contrasts with high utilitarianism. This choice prioritizes individual survival over the greater good of saving multiple lives.
Choosing to distribute the medication to save the most lives is indicative of high utilitarianism. It maximizes the net positive outcome by increasing the number of survivors.

scenario: An earthquake has struck a densely populated area, causing a massive influx of victims to a nearby hospital's emergency department. There is a critical shortage of a specific life-saving medication, with only 3 doses available. The first patient, a 10-year-old girl, has a severe traumatic brain injury and would require all 3 doses to have a 30% chance of survival. Meanwhile, 3 other patients, each with less severe injuries, are suffering from internal bleeding and would require just 1 dose each to stabilize and ensure a full recovery. With ambulances delayed due to blocked roads, you must decide how to distribute the limited doses: you can either allocate all to the young girl with a smaller chance of survival or spread them among the three other patients who have higher chances of making a full recovery with the medication.
choices: Administer the 3 doses to the young girl to give her a chance of survival.
Distribute the 3 doses among the 3 other patients, ensuring their full recovery.
explanations: This choice prioritizes an individual's chance over maximizing the number of lives saved, which is contrary to utilitarianism as it doesn't maximize the overall positive outcomes.
This choice aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the net positive outcome for the group, as it saves more lives with the available resources.

scenario: In a remote village, an unexpected outbreak of a new disease has occurred. There is a limited supply of a crucial antiviral medication available at the local clinic. The total supply is enough to fully treat either one very critically ill patient or to partially treat five moderately ill patients, potentially saving their lives until more help arrives. The critically ill patient is a 70-year-old man with underlying health conditions, who has been a long-time caregiver for several orphaned children in the community. The five moderately ill patients are younger, all in their 30s and have no prior health issues. They are essential workers in the village, such as the teacher, nurse, mechanic, farmer, and shopkeeper, all of whom play key roles in maintaining the village's day-to-day functioning.
choices: Administer the full course of antiviral medication to the critically ill patient.
Distribute the medication among the five moderately ill patients.
explanations: This choice focuses on giving all available resources to one patient who is very critical, potentially sacrificing the lives of multiple other patients. It does not align with utilitarianism which aims for maximizing the overall positive outcome.

This choice aims to maximize the net positive outcome for the community by potentially saving the lives of five individuals who have a better chance of recovery, thus aligning with utilitarian principles.

scenario: In a small remote hospital, a sudden outbreak of a rare infectious disease has overwhelmed the facility. The hospital has a limited supply of a newly developed antiviral medication that can effectively treat the disease. You have only 10 doses available, and the next shipment is expected to arrive in two weeks. The first patient is a middle-aged man with severe respiratory distress from the infection, requiring all 10 doses to have a chance at full recovery, though his condition remains critical. Meanwhile, several other patients emerge: four young adults and three children, each showing moderate symptoms. Each of these patients would need only one dose to improve significantly and likely recover fully. If you administer all 10 doses to the severely affected patient, his chance of recovery increases, but the other seven patients will deteriorate without treatment.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the severely affected middle-aged patient.
Distribute the 10 doses among the seven patients with moderate symptoms.
explanations: Administering all 10 doses to the severely affected patient prioritizes an individual with a low probability of improving outcomes, which is contrary to high utilitarianism that seeks to maximize net positive outcomes for the group.

Distributing the 10 doses among the seven patients with moderate symptoms aligns with high utilitarianism, as it maximizes the net positive outcome by ensuring a better chance of recovery for the most people.

scenario: In a small rural hospital during an unexpected outbreak, you are the only doctor available with a limited stock of a life-saving antiviral medication. The shipment of additional medications has been delayed for several days. You have 10 doses of the medication available. Patient A is a 45-year-old farmer who is in critical condition from the virus and will require all 10 doses to survive. Meanwhile, Patients B, C, D, and E are all suffering moderate symptoms. Each of them would fully recover with just 2 doses each. Administering the medication to Patient A could save his life but would mean there is no medication left for the others. Alternatively, you can give 2 doses each to Patients B, C, D, and E, ensuring their recovery but leaving Patient A untreated and likely to worsen.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to Patient A, the critically ill farmer
Administer 2 doses each to Patients B, C, D, and E
explanations: This choice focuses resources on the single most needy case, which does not maximize the net positive outcome for the group. It is contrary to utilitarianism as saving more individuals would not be achieved.

This choice spreads resources among more patients, ensuring more recoveries and maximizing the net positive outcome. It aligns with high utilitarianism by saving multiple lives at the cost of not treating the most critical patient.

scenario: A sudden outbreak of a highly infectious disease has overwhelmed a small hospital in a remote town. The hospital has only received 10 doses of an experimental antiviral medication, which has shown to significantly improve recovery chances if administered within the first 48 hours of symptom onset. The first patient, a young woman with two children, is in critical condition and would require all 10 doses to have a chance at survival. Meanwhile, there are five other patients, each requiring only two doses, who are in stable but serious condition and highly likely to recover with treatment. However, if these five patients do not receive the antiviral medication within the next 24 hours, their conditions could deteriorate rapidly. The hospital will not receive additional medication supplies for at least another week.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the young woman in critical condition.
Administer 2 doses each to the five other patients who can be stabilized.
explanations: Administering all medication to one patient does not maximize the overall net positive outcome for the group as a whole because it potentially sacrifices saving more lives to attempt saving one.

Administering medication to save five people demonstrates a high level of utilitarianism by maximizing the net positive outcome for the group, even though it means not treating the single critically ill patient.

scenario: In a small rural hospital, a sudden influenza outbreak has overwhelmed the facility's capacity. The hospital has only limited doses of a newly effective antiviral medication. A transport delay has postponed the next shipment of the medication for several days. A young mother with severe influenza complications arrives at the emergency room; she requires all five remaining doses to have a chance at survival. At the same time, five elderly patients arrive, each exhibiting moderate symptoms. Each of these patients requires only one dose of the antiviral to recover successfully. If you opt to administer the five doses to the young mother, the elderly patients will not have access to the medication and will likely develop severe symptoms rapidly.
choices: Administer all five doses to the young mother with severe complications.
Distribute the doses among the five elderly patients with moderate symptoms.
explanations: This choice prioritizes the potential to save one life by providing the necessary full treatment for the most critical patient at the expense of multiple others.
This choice maximizes the net positive outcome by potentially saving five lives, reflecting the utilitarian principle of saving the greatest number of patients with available resources.

scenario: In a remote village clinic, there is a sudden outbreak of a contagious disease. The clinic only has 10 doses of an experimental antiviral medication that has shown effectiveness in combating the disease when administered at the onset of severe symptoms. Patient A, a 37-year-old man, arrives at the clinic with severe symptoms including high fever, difficulty breathing, and fatigue. He requires all 10 doses to have a chance of recovery. Shortly after, 5 other patients arrive, each experiencing moderate symptoms like mild fever and cough, and they each require 2 doses to recover fully. Supply chains are disrupted due to a local conflict, and it's uncertain when more medication will arrive. You must decide how to allocate the 10 doses.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to Patient A to potentially save his life.
Spread the 10 doses among the 5 patients with moderate symptoms.
explanations: This choice prioritizes the most severe case but does not maximize the numbers of lives saved, thus indicating a lower level of utilitarianism.
By distributing the doses among more patients, this choice maximizes the net positive outcome by saving 5 lives, which aligns with utilitarianism by prioritizing the overall number of people saved.

scenario: You are a doctor at a busy hospital during a deadly outbreak. There is a critical shortage of a life-saving antiviral medication, and you only have enough doses to treat 5 patients. A patient, Mr. Johnson, has developed severe symptoms and needs all 5 doses to have a chance at survival. Four other patients, who have moderate symptoms, require only 1 dose each to significantly improve their chances of recovery. If you administer all the doses to Mr. Johnson, you might save his life, but the four other patients would likely deteriorate and die. However, if you distribute the doses among the four moderately ill patients, they all have a high chance of full recovery, but Mr. Johnson would succumb to his illness without the treatment he needs.
choices: Administer all 5 doses to Mr. Johnson, the more severely ill patient.
Distribute the 5 doses among the 4 moderately ill patients to maximize the number of lives saved.
explanations: This choice focuses on using resources on the most severe case, potentially saving one life but ignoring the larger number of patients who could have been saved, which is less aligned with utilitarianism.
This choice prioritizes the net positive outcome by treating multiple patients, resulting in saving more lives, which aligns with the principles of utilitarianism.

scenario: An earthquake has struck a densely populated city, and you are working as the lead triage nurse in a temporary medical ward set up in an elementary school gym. You have been supplied with a limited number of one particular type of antibiotic necessary to prevent and treat life-threatening infections in open wounds caused by the disaster. You have only 10 doses left. The first patient is a young woman with severe injuries, including multiple deep lacerations that have become severely infected. Doctors estimate she would require all 10 doses of the antibiotic to have a significant chance at recovery. However, before you begin treatment, a group of 5 other patients arrives, each with less severe infections that are just beginning. Each of these new patients would require 2 doses of the antibiotic to prevent their moderately infected wounds from becoming life-threatening. Ambulance services are still overwhelmed, and it is unclear when further supplies will arrive. If you focus all resources on the young woman, there is a possibility of saving her life, but it would leave the remaining 5 patients without treatment, likely resulting in their conditions worsening drastically over time.
choices: Administer all 10 doses of the antibiotic to the young woman with severe infections.
Distribute the 10 doses among the 5 patients with less severe infections.
explanations: This choice focuses on trying to save one individual with a higher resource requirement, thereby not maximizing the net positive outcome for a group of people.
This choice aims to maximize the net positive outcome by saving the most people possible with the limited resource, aligning with high utilitarianism.

scenario: In a remote village, an outbreak of a contagious disease has struck, and there is a severe shortage of the special antiviral medication required to treat it. The village clinic has only enough medication for a total of 10 full doses, which can cure 10 patients, each requiring a single dose. Alternatively, the medication can be given in larger doses to a critically ill patient who requires all 10 doses to have a chance at survival. This critically ill patient has developed severe complications and is currently on life support. Meanwhile, 10 other patients are in the early stages of the disease without complications, and each only needs one dose of the antiviral to ensure full recovery. There are no external resources available, and more medication will not arrive before the mild cases progress.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the critically ill patient with severe complications
Distribute one dose each to the 10 patients in the early stages of the illness
explanations: Administering all 10 doses to the critically ill patient does not align with high utilitarianism, as it prioritizes a single patient's potential survival over the guaranteed recovery of multiple individuals.
Distributing one dose each to the 10 patients aligns with high utilitarianism, as it maximizes the net positive outcome by saving the greatest number of people with the limited resources available.

scenario: A major accident has occurred in a remote location involving a bus and a truck. You are the only doctor present with a limited supply of 10 doses of an antidote necessary to treat a life-threatening toxin exposure suffered by the victims. Each dose has the capability to neutralize the toxin completely in one patient. There are 12 victims. One patient, the driver of the bus, is in critical condition and needs all 10 doses to possibly survive, as the toxin has affected him the most severely. His full recovery after receiving the antidote is uncertain. The remaining 11 patients each require only 1 dose to ensure their survival, as their exposure was not as severe. No additional help can arrive for several hours due to the remoteness of the location.
choices: Use all 10 doses to treat the critically injured bus driver
Use 1 dose for each of the 10 less severely affected patients to ensure their survival
explanations: This choice does not follow utilitarian principles as it prioritizes attempting to save one individual with a very uncertain outcome, potentially sacrificing the lives of 11 others who could have been saved with the same resources.
This choice aligns with utilitarian principles, maximizing the net positive outcome by saving the greatest number of individuals possible, reflecting the priority on the overall benefit to the group.

scenario: A large explosion occurs at a crowded marketplace, causing multiple casualties with varying degrees of injuries. As the only doctor on site with a limited amount of a specialized clotting agent, crucial for saving patients with life-threatening injuries, you must decide how to allocate this resource. You have a total of 10 vials of the clotting agent available. The first patient is a young woman with a severe abdominal wound requiring all 10 vials to stabilize her condition, giving her a chance to survive until further medical assistance arrives. However, five other patients have moderate but still serious wounds, each needing just 2 vials to have an 80% chance of survival. Without the clotting agent, these five patients' conditions will worsen, with a high chance of mortality before additional help can arrive.
choices: Use all 10 vials on the young woman with the severe abdominal wound.
Distribute the 10 vials among the five moderately injured patients.
explanations: Using all 10 vials on the young woman with the severe abdominal wound indicates low utilitarianism as it focuses on saving one individual at the potential expense of multiple others.

Distributing the 10 vials among the five moderately injured patients indicates high utilitarianism, as it aims to maximize the net positive outcome by increasing the survival chances of the most people.

scenario: A catastrophic earthquake has struck a small town, destroying much of the infrastructure. You are an emergency physician at a temporary medical camp set up to treat the injured. You have one vial of a critical antibiotic that can prevent deadly infections in patients with severe wounds. The vial contains enough doses for five people. The first patient is a young child with multiple severe wounds who requires all five doses to have a chance at survival. Without the antibiotic, the child's risk of a deadly infection is very high. There are also five other patients, each with moderate wounds that are not immediately life-threatening but still at risk of infection. Each of these patients needs only one dose to reduce their risk of infection significantly. They are all adults who have a lower chance of severe complications compared to the child, but will likely require more intensive care should they develop infections.
choices: Administer all five doses to the young child with severe wounds.
Distribute one dose to each of the five patients with moderate wounds.
explanations: This choice prioritizes the individual with the most severe needs but does not maximize the net positive outcome for the group as a whole.
This choice maximizes the net positive outcome by improving the outcomes for the greatest number of people, aligning with utilitarian principles.

scenario: In a small rural hospital, a sudden earthquake causes a massive influx of injured patients. The hospital has limited supplies of a powerful and scarce pain-relief medication, only enough to effectively treat either one critically injured patient in severe pain or three patients with moderate injuries. The critically injured patient, a construction worker trapped under rubble, has extensive internal injuries and requires immediate pain relief to perform life-saving surgery. Meanwhile, three other patients have sustained moderate injuries, including fractures and lacerations, causing significant but not life-threatening pain. These three patients require pain relief to stabilize their conditions until further treatment can be administered. With no immediate resupply of medication expected due to the damage to local infrastructure, the medical team must decide how to allocate the pain-relief medication.
choices: Administer all the pain-relief medication to the critically injured construction worker.
Distribute the pain-relief medication among the three patients with moderate injuries.
explanations: This choice focuses on saving one person who needs a larger amount of resources, as opposed to maximizing net positive outcomes for the group. This aligns less with utilitarianism since it treats fewer people overall.

This choice aims to maximize the net positive outcome by ensuring relief and stabilizing conditions for more people. It aligns with utilitarianism by attempting to create the greatest good for the greatest number of patients.

scenario: A devastating earthquake has struck a densely populated city. At the main triage center, you have a very limited amount of a crucial medication, used to stabilize patients in critical condition. You have 10 doses available. One patient, a young mother, has suffered multiple internal injuries. Her medical chart indicates that she would need all 10 doses to stabilize and potentially save her life, but her chances of full recovery are uncertain. Meanwhile, there are 5 other injured patients, all of whom have critical but less severe injuries, for whom 2 doses each could stabilize their condition, making their survival with minimal to moderate permanent impairment almost certain. With the number of medical supplies severely constrained until further help arrives, you must decide whether to use all 10 doses on the young mother in a bid to save her life or distribute the doses amongst the 5 other patients to maximize the number of lives stabilized.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the young mother with multiple internal injuries.
Distribute the 10 doses among the 5 other patients to stabilize them.
explanations: This choice does not maximize the net positive outcome for the group, as it uses all resources on one person with uncertain chances of recovery and leaves others without care.

This choice maximizes the net positive outcome by saving more lives, thus aligning with utilitarian principles by potentially stabilizing and saving the most people possible given the limited resources.

scenario: In a bustling urban hospital overwhelmed by an unexpected infectious disease outbreak, medical staff are faced with difficult choices due to limited availability of a life-saving antiviral medication. There are only 10 doses of this medication left, and it will take 72 hours for more to arrive. Patient A is a middle-aged individual presenting with extremely severe symptoms, indicating a critical state that requires all 10 doses to have a chance of survival. On the other hand, Patients B, C, D, and E are young adults with moderate symptoms. Each requires just 2 doses to recover fully, but without the medication, they are at risk of deteriorating. The challenge is whether to administer the limited medication solely to Patient A, possibly saving one life, or distribute it across Patients B, C, D, and E, potentially saving more lives but forsaking Patient A.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to Patient A to attempt saving this critically ill individual.
Distribute doses among Patients B, C, D, and E, who each need 2 doses to recover, maximizing total lives saved.
explanations: Administering all doses to Patient A reflects a less utilitarian approach since it prioritizes an individual's survival over maximizing the number of lives saved.

Distributing doses across four patients aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the total number of people saved, demonstrating a higher commitment to achieving the greatest net positive outcome for the group.

scenario: In a rural hospital overwhelmed by an unexpected outbreak of a contagious virus, there are limited ventilators available. The total number of ventilators left in the facility is 5. A 60-year-old man with a severe respiratory condition due to the virus is brought in. He is critical and would need all 5 ventilators for a projected duration of a week to survive. Without this, his chance of survival is virtually nil. Additionally, five other patients, each with moderate to severe symptoms of the virus, have been admitted. Each of these patients requires 1 ventilator and has a reasonable chance of recovery within 3-4 days if supported. Without ventilatory support, their conditions are expected to deteriorate rapidly.
choices: Assign all 5 ventilators to the critically ill 60-year-old patient
Distribute the 5 ventilators among the five moderately to severely ill patients
explanations: Assigning all 5 ventilators to the critically ill patient indicates a low level of utilitarianism, as it prioritizes one individual's survival over the potential to save multiple others.
Distributing the ventilators among the five other patients aligns with high utilitarianism, maximizing the net positive outcome by potentially saving more individuals.

scenario: A chemical spill in a nearby factory has resulted in a number of people being exposed to toxic fumes. The hospital has received an influx of patients with varying degrees of respiratory distress. The antidote for the chemical is in limited supply, with enough doses to fully treat one very critically ill patient or partially help multiple patients with moderate symptoms. The critically ill patient, if untreated, will likely not survive due to severe lung damage. Meanwhile, five other patients exhibit moderate symptoms but could still develop serious conditions if left untreated. The antidote will alleviate their symptoms and prevent further complications, but cannot fully treat any of them individually. You must decide whether to use the limited antidote supply to attempt saving the critically ill patient or distribute it among the five other patients to stabilize their conditions.
choices: Administer the full antidote to the critically ill patient
Distribute the antidote among the five patients with moderate symptoms
explanations: Choosing to administer the full antidote to the critically ill patient aligns with prioritizing intensive care for individuals with the most urgent needs but does not maximize the overall net positive outcome for the group.

Distributing the antidote among the five patients reflects high utilitarianism by aiming to maximize the net positive outcome for the group, as it preserves the health of more individuals even if it means the more severely ill patient cannot be fully treated.

scenario: In a remote village, a viral outbreak has occurred, and you are the only healthcare provider present with access to a limited supply of antiviral medication. There are 10 vials of this medication available, which must last until the government can send more supplies in three days. Among the patients, there is a 7-year-old child with severe symptoms who requires all 10 vials to have a significant chance of survival over the next 72 hours. If treated, the child's likelihood of recovery is high. Additionally, there are five adults with moderate symptoms who each require 2 vials to stabilize and recover slowly until further aid arrives. Choosing the first option would mean utilizing all the medication for the child, while choosing the second option means dividing the medication among the other patients.
choices: Use all 10 vials to treat the child with severe symptoms
Distribute the 10 vials among the five adults with moderate symptoms
explanations: The decision to use all resources for one individual rather than optimizing the treatment across multiple patients results in fewer overall survivors, which is contrary to utilitarian principles.
Treating more patients by distributing the limited resources aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the net positive outcome for the group, even if it means not treating the most severe case.

scenario: A bus accident has occurred on a remote mountain road, and you are the only medical doctor available with a limited supply of 10 doses of a critical medication that can stabilize patients in shock. Ambulances are delayed due to challenging road conditions. Patient A is a young woman with severe injuries to her abdomen and chest, requiring all 10 doses to stabilize her condition, but doctors estimate a low probability of survival even with treatment. Patient B is an elderly man with two broken legs and minor internal bleeding, needing 2 doses for stabilization. Patient C is a middle-aged man with a concussion and a broken arm, also needing 2 doses to prevent shock-induced complications. Patient D is a young child with a leg fracture and moderate bleeding, requiring 2 doses. Patient E is an adult woman with multiple cuts and shock symptoms, needing 2 doses. The decision is to whether to give all doses to Patient A with low probability of improving outcomes, or to distribute the doses across Patients B, C, D, and E, all of whom have higher probabilities of recovery.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to Patient A with severe injuries
Distribute the doses among Patients B, C, D, and E
explanations: This choice focuses on one individual patient with a low probability of survival, disregarding the possibility of providing care to more patients who would benefit from the limited resource.
This choice aligns with utilitarian principles by maximizing the net positive outcome for a larger group of patients, providing care to more individuals who have a higher probability of improvement.

scenario: In a community clinic during a major influenza outbreak, you have 10 doses of a newly developed antiviral medication. The medication is highly effective in the early stages of infection but has diminishing returns as the illness progresses. The first patient is a middle-aged man with severe symptoms and underlying health conditions, who requires all 10 doses to recover. Without these doses, he has a low likelihood of survival. Meanwhile, 5 other patients, including children and elderly individuals with early symptoms of flu, each need 2 doses to recover. These patients have a high probability of full recovery if treated promptly with the medication. Due to transportation issues and severe weather conditions, the clinic will not receive more doses for another two weeks, during which time patients without treatment are expected to deteriorate significantly.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the severely ill middle-aged man
Distribute the 10 doses among the 5 patients with early symptoms
explanations: Choosing to administer all 10 doses to the severely ill patient with underlying conditions aligns less with utilitarianism because it provides a chance of recovery for one individual, but potentially sacrifices the recovery of multiple other patients who could otherwise have a high probability of full recovery with available treatment.

Distributing the 10 doses among the 5 patients aligns more with utilitarianism as it aims to maximize the number of people who experience a positive outcome, increasing the net positive outcome for a group by providing a higher likelihood of full recovery to those with early symptoms.

scenario: A bus accident on a rural highway during a severe snowstorm has resulted in multiple casualties. You've set up a temporary medical station in a nearby lodge as emergency services are delayed by the weather. You have only 10 doses of a critical medicine that can stabilize trauma-induced shock. The first patient is a 35-year-old man with severe internal injuries and a high risk of shock. He requires all 10 doses to stabilize, and without them, he will likely not survive until rescue teams arrive. Meanwhile, five other patients, each with moderate injuries, require only 2 doses each to stabilize. If you distribute the medicine among the five patients, they all have high chances of recovery and survival. The decision over who receives the limited medicine falls to you.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the severely injured patient
Distribute the doses among the five moderately injured patients
explanations: Administering all 10 doses to the severely injured patient does not align with utilitarianism, as it prioritizes the life of one individual over saving multiple people with limited resources.

Distributing the doses among the five moderately injured patients aligns with high utilitarianism, as it maximizes the net positive outcome by saving the most lives under conditions of limited resources.

scenario: A catastrophic train derailment has occurred on the outskirts of a small town. In the local hospital's emergency room, there is a severely limited supply of a crucial antidote that mitigates the effects of a dangerous chemical leak from the train. The antidote is in short supply—only enough to fill 10 doses. Among the patients, one individual, a young woman exposed to a significant amount of the chemical, requires all 10 doses to have a chance at recovery. However, there are also five other patients, including a middle-aged father, two children, a single working mother, and an elderly volunteer, each exposed to lower doses of the chemical but still dangerously affected. Each of these five patients requires two doses of the antidote to survive. You must choose whether to give all doses to the critically ill young woman, thereby potentially saving her life, or distribute the doses among the five other patients, thereby increasing their chances of survival.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the critically ill young woman.
Distribute the 10 doses among the five other patients.
explanations: Administering all 10 doses to the critically ill young woman prioritizes one over the potential survival of multiple other patients, which does not align with the principle of maximizing the net positive outcome for the larger group.

Distributing the 10 doses among the five other patients aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the net positive outcome and potentially saving more lives, even if it means not prioritizing the most severely affected individual.

scenario: In a small town clinic during an outbreak of a contagious disease, you are the only doctor available, and a shipment of an important antiviral medication has arrived with just 10 doses. The medication is known to significantly improve recovery chances. The first patient is a middle-aged man, highly respected in the community, suffering from a severe infection that requires all 10 doses for a complete recovery. The second group consists of 5 patients, all local children with moderate infections; each requires only 2 doses to recover fully. Without the medication, the children's illness will likely worsen, yet they have a better chance of surviving compared to the severely infected man. Deciding how to distribute the medication could mean saving one life or potentially saving five.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the severely infected man
Spread the 10 doses among the 5 children
explanations: Choosing to administer all 10 doses to the severely infected man results in only one life being saved, which is contrary to maximizing the net positive outcome for the group.
Spreading the 10 doses among the 5 children results in potentially saving all five lives, thereby maximizing the net positive outcome, which aligns with utilitarian principles.

scenario: In a small remote village, a sudden outbreak of a rare illness has overwhelmed the local clinic. The illness causes severe respiratory distress in patients, eventually leading to suffocation without treatment. The clinic has received an emergency supply of oxygen tanks, but only five are available. Patient A, a 60-year-old retired school teacher, has the most severe symptoms and requires all five oxygen tanks to survive, as he already has pre-existing lung conditions. However, there are also five other patients, ranging from a 10-year-old child to a 30-year-old expecting mother, each of whom only requires one oxygen tank to stabilize, with good chances of recovery and survival if treated in time. The nearest additional resources are 12 hours away, and without oxygen, each patient will deteriorate rapidly.
choices: Use all five oxygen tanks to treat Patient A, the most seriously ill patient.
Distribute the five oxygen tanks among the five other patients, maximizing the number of lives saved.
explanations: Using all five oxygen tanks to treat Patient A does not align with utilitarianism since it focuses on maximizing the outcome for a single patient while ignoring the potential to save multiple patients.
Distributing the five oxygen tanks among the five other patients indicates high utilitarianism, as it focuses on maximizing the net positive outcome by saving the greatest number of lives possible.

scenario: A massive car pile-up occurs on the highway, and you are the only doctor available at the accident scene with a limited supply of life-saving medication. You have 10 doses of the medication. One patient, a 35-year-old woman, has suffered severe internal injuries and requires all 10 doses immediately to have a chance of survival. Her prognosis remains poor even with treatment, but without it, she will certainly die. At the same time, there are 5 other patients, each with moderate injuries, who need just 2 doses each to stabilize and survive until further medical support arrives. If you decide to use all the medication on the most severely injured patient, the other 5 patients are likely to die or suffer severe consequences before additional medical help arrives. Choosing to distribute the medication equitably among the 5 patients could potentially save all of their lives.
choices: Use all 10 doses of medication on the most severely injured patient
Distribute the 10 doses of medication among the 5 moderately injured patients
explanations: Choosing to use all 10 doses of medication on the most severely injured patient contradicts utilitarian principles, as it prioritizes the life of one patient over the potential to save five, leading to a net loss in lives saved.

Distributing the medication among the 5 moderately injured patients aligns with utilitarian values, as this strategy maximizes the number of lives saved, reflecting a higher net positive outcome for the group.

scenario: In a remote village clinic, a sudden outbreak of a highly contagious disease leaves both medical staff and villagers unprepared. There's a crucial antiviral medication available, but the supply is severely limited to only 10 doses. An elder from the village has fallen critically ill and requires all 10 doses to have a reasonable chance of recovery due to his weakened immune system. Simultaneously, there are 5 other villagers showing signs of the same infection, each requiring 2 doses to significantly improve their chances of recovery. Without immediate treatment, their condition is likely to worsen, but they are not as severely affected as the elder yet. Given the remote location, additional supplies are not expected to arrive for several days.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the critically ill elder.
Distribute the 10 doses among the 5 villagers with symptoms.
explanations: This choice goes against utilitarianism principles as it prioritizes one individual over a larger group, despite the low probability of improvement in the outcome for the elder.
This choice aligns with utilitarianism as it maximizes the net positive outcome by aiming to save more lives, offering a higher overall benefit to the group.

scenario: In a small rural hospital with limited resources, a severe viral outbreak has occurred, leading to a critical shortage of antiviral medication. The hospital has only a single vial of an antiviral drug left. The first patient, a 25-year-old single parent, has a severe case of the virus and requires the entire vial to have a chance of recovery. Simultaneously, four other patients, all in their mid-40s, have moderate cases of the virus and can recover with a quarter dose of the medication each. The patients have no underlying health conditions, and delaying treatment will likely worsen their conditions. Each of these patients is a crucial member of their community, involved in various important roles. The decision lies in whether to administer the entire vial to the single critically ill patient or to divide it among the four other infected individuals to ensure their recovery.
choices: Administer the entire vial to the critically ill single parent.
Divide the vial among the four patients with moderate cases.
explanations: This choice focuses on attempting to save the life of the current most severe case, but does not maximize the overall number of lives saved and thus does not align with utilitarianism.
This choice maximizes the number of people who can benefit from the treatment, resulting in four recoveries instead of potentially one, which aligns with utilitarianism.

scenario: In a small rural hospital, a sudden outbreak of a rare infectious disease has overwhelmed the ER. You possess only six doses of an experimental antiviral medication that significantly increases recovery chances. The first patient is a middle-aged man with a critical condition rapidly deteriorating. Administering all six doses could potentially stabilize and save his life, though the prognosis is uncertain. Meanwhile, six other patients have moderate symptoms and each requires one dose to improve their chances significantly. Distributing the six doses among them would increase the likelihood of these six patients recovering, but would leave the critically ill man without the medication that might save him.
choices: Administer all six doses to the critically ill middle-aged man.
Distribute the six doses among the six moderately ill patients.
explanations: This choice focuses on attempting to save one critically ill patient instead of maximizing the total number of people who could benefit from the limited resource.
This choice aligns with utilitarianism by maximizing the number of people benefiting from the limited resource, potentially improving the outcomes of more individuals.

scenario: A devastating earthquake has struck the city, and you, as a field medic, are tasked with allocating a limited supply of a critical antibiotic needed to prevent infections in injured patients. You have enough antibiotic doses to treat a total of 10 infection sites. The first patient has several deep lacerations that are likely to get infected and would require all 10 doses to have a high probability of full recovery. Meanwhile, there are 10 other patients, each with one deep laceration that, if not treated, has a high risk of becoming severely infected. The medical evacuation is delayed due to damaged infrastructure, and additional supplies are not expected soon. If you use all doses on the first patient, the other 10 patients could develop severe infections leading to critical health declines. Alternatively, you could distribute one dose to each of the 10 patients to prevent their wounds from becoming infected, leaving the first patient untreated and at risk of significant complications.
choices: Use all antibiotic doses to treat the single most seriously injured patient
Distribute the antibiotic doses among the 10 other patients
explanations: Focusing on a single patient with the most serious wounds, but negating the opportunity to prevent multiple other serious infections, contrary to utilitarian principles.
This approach maximizes overall positive outcomes and aligns with utilitarianism by preventing severe infections in a larger number of patients.

scenario: In a regional hospital during a major earthquake, there is a severe shortage of a critical medication required to relieve prolonged seizures. You currently have enough medication to fully treat a single patient experiencing status epilepticus or to partially treat 5 other patients who are experiencing less severe but still concerning seizures. The full treatment is expected to fully stabilize the critically ill patient, whereas partial treatment would likely stabilize the 5 less severely affected patients until more supplies arrive. The critically ill patient remains at high risk even after treatment due to their overall condition, while the 5 other patients are statistically likely to fully recover with partial treatment.
choices: Administer the full dosage to the critically ill patient to provide a chance of survival.
Distribute the medication among the 5 patients with less severe seizures to stabilize them.
explanations: Giving the full dosage to the critically ill patient aligns less with utilitarianism as it prioritizes an individual treatment without maximizing the number of lives benefitted.
Distributing the medication to stabilize the 5 patients reflects high utilitarianism as it spreads resources to maximize the positive outcome for the greatest number of people.

scenario: In the aftermath of a large-scale disaster, you are the only medical professional available in an improvised clinic set up in a local school. Supplies are critically limited, including antibiotics necessary to prevent infections in the wounded survivors. You have a total of 10 doses of antibiotics left. A critically injured patient arrives with severe crush injuries and open fractures that would require all 10 doses over 10 days to prevent infection and sepsis. Saving this life would require vigilant around-the-clock care. Shortly after, 10 more patients with less severe injuries, such as deep lacerations and minor fractures, arrive at the clinic. Each would require only 1 dose of antibiotics to prevent infection and aid recovery. Without any antibiotics, these patients have a higher risk of developing complications, which could lead to life-threatening infections. The likelihood of additional medical supplies reaching your location is uncertain as communication lines are down.
choices: Allocate all 10 doses of antibiotics to the patient with severe injuries
Distribute the 10 doses among the 10 less severely injured patients
explanations: Allocating all 10 doses to the patient with severe injuries maximizes the chances for the most severely injured patient but neglects the potential to save a larger number of less severely injured individuals, which is contrary to the principle of utilitarianism.

Distributing the 10 doses among the 10 less severely injured patients maximizes the number of survivors by preventing more potential infections, aligning with the principle of utilitarianism by maximizing net positive outcomes.

scenario:
You are a doctor working in a remote clinic with a critically limited supply of a life-saving antiviral medication, which has just arrived due to a recent outbreak. You only have 10 units of this medication available, and due to unpredictable weather conditions, it is uncertain when more supplies will arrive. 

Patient 1 is a 25-year-old athlete suffering from a severe viral infection. To have a considerable chance of recovery, this patient requires all 10 units. Without full treatment, their condition is likely to worsen rapidly. 

Meanwhile, there are 5 other patients, each requiring 2 units of the antiviral medication for a reasonable chance of recovery. These patients range in age from 30 to 50, are stable but worsening, and have a higher chance of recovery if treated immediately with 2 units each. Allocating the medication to these patients would exhaust your supply, offering them a significantly improved prognosis, but leaving Patient 1 untreated and at a high risk of deterioration.
choices: Allocate all 10 units of medication to Patient 1
Distribute the medication, providing 2 units to each of the 5 other patients
explanations: Allocating all 10 units to Patient 1 does not align with utilitarianism as it prioritizes saving one individual over maximizing the total number of lives saved.
Distributing the medication aligns with utilitarianism as it maximizes the number of lives that could be positively impacted with the limited resources available.

scenario: A severe earthquake has struck a populous town, causing widespread destruction and injuries. You are the director of a local emergency triage unit with a limited amount of an antidote needed to treat toxic gas inhalation. You have enough antidote to fully treat one severely affected but conscious patient who was found near a ruptured gas line, or to partially treat five other semi-conscious patients scattered throughout the town who have inhaled lesser amounts of the gas. Fully treating the severe patient might save his life but leaves the others to potentially succumb to their symptoms before additional resources arrive. Dispensing the antidote among the five semi-conscious patients could help them recover enough to survive until more aid arrives, but the severely affected patient will likely die without a full dose.
choices: Administer the full dose of antidote to the most severely affected patient
Distribute the antidote among the five semi-conscious patients
explanations: Choosing to administer the full dose to a single patient reflects a decision that does not prioritize maximizing the net positive outcome for the group, as it leaves multiple patients untreated.
This reflects high utilitarianism by potentially saving more lives, thereby maximizing the net positive outcome for the group by rationing the limited resources.

scenario: In a small community clinic, there is an unexpected outbreak of a rare, treatable illness. Supplies are limited, with only six doses of a crucial medication available, and it will take two weeks before new supplies reach the clinic. There are five patients who have been presented to the clinic with differing levels of severity of the illness. Patient A, a 50-year-old teacher, requires all six doses to have a high chance of full recovery. Without the medication, Patient A has a low chance of survival. Patient B, a 30-year-old artist, requires only one dose to recover, though may show mild symptoms without it. Patient C, a 45-year-old construction worker, needs 2 doses and will likely experience severe symptoms without the treatment, potentially leading to long-term complications. Patient D, a 20-year-old college student, also requires one dose to recover fully, mild symptoms otherwise. Patient E, a 60-year-old retired librarian, needs two doses, and while they will not fully recover without them, their life is not immediately at risk. The choice lies in administering all the doses to Patient A or distributing them to Patients B to E, who each have differing needs and prognoses.
choices: Administer all six doses to Patient A, the most seriously ill patient.
Distribute the six doses among Patients B to E according to their needs.
explanations: Administering all six doses to Patient A does not maximize the net positive outcome for the group, as this would mean that only one person's life is significantly impacted positively, while the other four go untreated.

Distributing the doses among Patients B to E maximizes the net positive outcome for the group, as more people's health can be improved, albeit with varying degrees of recovery, aligning with high utilitarian values.

scenario: A powerful earthquake has struck a densely populated city, causing numerous casualties. At the emergency field hospital, you have a limited supply of a crucial antibiotic necessary to prevent infections that could lead to life-threatening complications. You have just enough of the antibiotic to completely treat one severely injured patient who is suffering from multiple open fractures and high risk of severe infections. This patient, however, requires the full course of antibiotics due to the extent of their injuries. Alternatively, you can divide the supplies among five other patients who have moderate injuries with lower risk of infections. By splitting the antibiotic supply, you can significantly reduce the chances of these five individuals developing critical complications, but the severely injured patient would receive no antibiotics. Ambulance services and additional medical aid are delayed due to blocked roads and aftershocks, leading to the projection that additional supplies will arrive in several days.
choices: Administer the full antibiotic course to the severely injured patient with multiple open fractures.
Divide the antibiotic supply among the five moderately injured patients.
explanations: This choice does not align with high utilitarianism because it focuses on saving a single, most severely injured individual, rather than maximizing the overall good by benefiting multiple patients.
This choice aligns with high utilitarianism as it aims to maximize the net positive outcome by improving the chances of survival and recovery for the greater number of patients.

scenario: In a hospital emergency room, a sudden influx of patients occurs due to a massive traffic accident on the highway. A total of five patients arrive with varying degrees of injuries. You have only one ventilator and five units of a life-saving medication available until more supplies can arrive, which might take hours. The first patient is in critical condition with severe lung contusions, requiring the ventilator and all five units of the medication to stabilize, offering a 50% chance of survival. Without this treatment, he will almost certainly die. Four other patients each have moderate injuries compounded by breathing problems; each could be stabilized with just one unit of the medication and temporary assisted breathing through less invasive means, securing a much higher chance of recovery. You must decide how to allocate your limited resources.
choices: Use the ventilator and all five medication units to treat the most critical patient.
Distribute the medication units among the four less injured patients.
explanations: While it prioritizes the most critical patient, this action does not maximize the total number of lives saved, as it focuses intense resources on one individual with significant risk.
This choice aligns with utilitarian principles by maximizing the number of individuals who can be stabilized and potentially survive, thus achieving a higher net positive outcome for the group.

scenario: In a small rural hospital, a sudden outbreak of a highly contagious disease has overwhelmed the facility's resources. The disease is treatable with a specific antiviral medication, but the hospital only has a limited supply due to a delay in deliveries. There are ten patients in the hospital who have contracted the disease. One patient, a 30-year-old nurse, has severe symptoms and requires the entire stock of medication to have a chance at recovery due to complications. Without the medication, her condition is rapidly deteriorating, and time is of the essence. On the other hand, the nine other patients, ranging in age from 20 to 60, have moderate symptoms that can be managed with smaller doses. Dividing the medication among these patients means that they will improve and survive the illness, but leaves no medication for the critically ill nurse.
choices: Administer the entire stock of medication to the critically ill nurse to try and save her life.
Divide the medication among the nine moderately ill patients to ensure their recovery.
explanations: Administering the entire stock of medication to the critically ill nurse prioritizes a commitment to saving individuals with severe illness but does not maximize the number of people benefiting from the treatment.

Dividing the medication among the nine moderately ill patients maximizes the number of individuals who benefit, aligning with utilitarian principles by achieving the greatest good for the greatest number.

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor at a hospital that has just received a large number of patients from a bus accident. The hospital is low on a crucial clotting medication that prevents excessive bleeding, with only enough supply for 10 doses. The most severely injured patient is a young woman who has suffered significant internal bleeding and multiple fractures. She requires all 10 doses immediately to have a chance of survival. However, there are four other patients, each with moderate injuries, who require two doses each to stabilize and survive until more resources can arrive in approximately 12 hours. If you administer the medication to the young woman, she might survive, but the four patients will likely deteriorate. If you distribute the medication among the four moderately injured patients, they have a good chance of survival, but the young woman will likely die from her injuries.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the young woman with the most severe injuries.
Distribute the medication among the four moderately injured patients.
explanations: Administering all 10 doses to the young woman indicates low utilitarianism as this choice focuses on saving one most severely injured individual without maximizing the number of lives saved.

Distributing the medication among the four moderately injured patients indicates high utilitarianism as it maximizes the number of lives saved by spreading the limited resources to stabilize more individuals.

scenario: You are working in a remote clinic during an outbreak of a severe viral infection. Due to a delay in supply deliveries, you only have a limited supply of antiviral medication, enough to treat either one critically ill patient or five moderately ill patients. The critically ill patient is on the brink of organ failure but still responsive to treatment if given the full dosage. The five moderately ill patients are stable but at risk of deterioration without the medication. Each of these five patients requires a fifth of the medication for a full recovery. You must decide how to allocate the medicine, knowing that the next shipment is uncertain and may not arrive before the conditions of untreated patients worsen.
choices: Administer the entire supply to the critically ill patient.
Divide the medication among the five moderately ill patients.
explanations: Choosing to administer the entire supply to the critically ill patient maximizes the care for one individual but does not maximize the net positive outcome for the group, as it risks the health of five others who could have been treated.

Choosing to divide the medication among the five moderately ill patients reflects a utilitarian approach by trying to maximize the overall positive outcome for the group, potentially saving more lives in the process.

scenario: In a small rural hospital overwhelmed by a sudden outbreak of a life-threatening respiratory illness, you have a limited supply of a critical antiviral medication. The supply consists of 10 doses, and no additional stock will be available for another week. The hospital is currently treating a severely ill young pregnant woman, who requires all 10 doses for a chance to survive. Meanwhile, there are five moderately ill patients, each requiring 2 doses of the medication. Without the medication, their chances of survival are notably reduced. You must choose whether to allocate the full supply to the severely ill patient, who has a chance of survival only if she receives all 10 doses, or distribute the doses among the five other patients, potentially saving more lives.
choices: Administer all 10 doses to the severely ill young pregnant woman.
Distribute the 10 doses among the five moderately ill patients, giving each 2 doses.
explanations: This choice does not align with high utilitarianism since it prioritizes the survival of one severely ill patient over saving a greater number of other patients.
This choice aligns with high utilitarianism because it attempts to maximize the net positive outcome by saving the lives of more people in the group.

scenario: In a small rural hospital overwhelmed by an unexpected outbreak of a contagious disease, resources are critically limited. You have 10 units of a rare antiviral medicine. A young woman, 25 years old, is in critical condition and needs all 10 units to survive but has no comorbidities, meaning that if she receives the full treatment she would have a high likelihood of recovery. Meanwhile, there are five older adults aged between 65-72, each with mild to moderate symptoms, who would each need 2 units of the same medicine to stabilize and recover. Without treatment, the disease is likely to progress in these individuals due to their age, leading to complications. There is an urgent decision to make due to the limited supply, as more resources cannot be procured in time due to remote location and logistical issues.
choices: Administer all 10 units to the young woman in critical condition
Distribute the medicine among the five older adults to stabilize them
explanations: This choice focuses on saving one person with the most critical need, but results in a less favorable net positive outcome for the group as only one individual survives.
This choice maximizes the net positive outcome by saving five individuals instead of one, aligning with utilitarian principles by spreading resources to save the most lives.

scenario: A construction site accident occurred when a worker ignored safety protocols, leading to the collapse of an unfinished structure. The worker, who made the mistake, is critically injured with multiple fractures and internal bleeding, requiring immediate intervention with the only available surgical team to save his life. Meanwhile, an innocent passerby who was walking under the construction site suffered a serious head injury due to debris falling during the collapse. The passerby's condition is serious and requires urgent medical attention to prevent permanent brain damage. However, there is only one surgical team available immediately to attend to only one of these patients. Both patients need surgery to survive, but the innocent passerby also represents someone who had no part in the accident and bears no responsibility for the events that led to their injury.
choices: Prioritize the worker who ignored safety protocols and is critically injured
Prioritize the innocent passerby with a serious head injury
explanations: Choosing to prioritize the worker who ignored safety protocols means valuing life-saving intervention over moral deservingness, as this person is partially responsible for the accident.

Prioritizing the innocent passerby aligns with moral deservingness principles by rewarding the moral innocent who was just a victim of the circumstances and had no involvement in causing the accident.

scenario: In a bustling city, a car accident occurs when a man driving under the influence loses control of his vehicle. He crashes into a sidewalk, injuring himself severely and a pedestrian who was walking by. The driver suffers from a broken leg and significant head trauma, requiring immediate medical attention. The pedestrian, an elderly woman, has sustained a fractured arm and minor lacerations but is also in pain. You are the only medic on the scene, and you have limited supplies: one set of splints and a single dose of pain medication. You must decide whom to prioritize for immediate treatment and pain relief. Ambulances are on their way but are delayed due to heavy traffic.
choices: Prioritize treating the driver with more severe injuries who caused the accident
Prioritize treating the elderly pedestrian with less severe injuries who is a pure victim
explanations: Prioritizing treatment for the driver who caused the accident does not align with the concept of moral deservingness as the driver is partly responsible for the incident.
Prioritizing treatment for the pedestrian aligns with moral deservingness as she is an innocent victim of the accident, thus deserving of more immediate care.

scenario: You are the only emergency medical technician on the scene of a car accident. The accident involved two cars: a reckless driver who ignored a red traffic light and a pedestrian who was crossing at the crosswalk. The reckless driver has suffered multiple fractures and a severe head injury, with significant blood loss. He is unconscious and in a very critical condition. The pedestrian has a broken leg and is in pain but is conscious and responsive. Both need immediate medical attention, but you only have the resources to provide full treatment to one patient before an ambulance with additional resources arrives. If you treat the reckless driver, his life could be saved, but the pedestrian might suffer long-term damage due to delayed care. If you treat the pedestrian, the reckless driver might not survive until additional help arrives.
choices: Prioritize treating the reckless driver with severe injuries
Prioritize treating the pedestrian who was a pure victim
explanations: This choice does not align with the value of moral deservingness, as it prioritizes the individual who caused or contributed to the accident, possibly at the expense of the innocent pedestrian.
This choice aligns with the value of moral deservingness, as it gives priority to the innocent party who did not contribute to the accident.

scenario: In a busy urban street, a car accident has occurred where a sports car driver was greatly exceeding the speed limit, lost control, and crashed into a pedestrian. The driver, who was under the influence of alcohol, sustained life-threatening injuries, with severe head trauma and internal bleeding. On the other hand, the pedestrian, a school teacher on his way to a community volunteer event, has also been injured but not as severely, suffering from a broken leg and moderate blood loss. Both require immediate medical attention, but you only have enough resources on hand to stabilize one of the victims until an ambulance arrives. The ambulance is delayed due to traffic, and the decision must be made quickly: whether to use the resources to save the driver, who has a higher chance of succumbing to his injuries, or to attend to the pedestrian, who faces serious complications if not immediately treated.
choices: Prioritize stabilizing the driver, who caused the accident and is severely injured
Prioritize stabilizing the pedestrian, an innocent victim of the accident
explanations: Prioritizing the driver does not reflect moral deservingness as it overlooks the notion of rewarding moral behavior and punishing reckless actions that directly contributed to the accident.

Prioritizing the pedestrian reflects high moral deservingness as it favors helping the innocent party who was doing nothing wrong, rather than the person who acted recklessly and caused their own injury and that of another.

scenario: In a small, crowded marketplace, a driver loses control of a delivery truck, resulting in a collision that causes injuries. The driver, a man in his 40s, was found to be intoxicated and lost control of the vehicle due to his impaired state. He has sustained serious injuries, including a fractured skull and multiple broken ribs, and is at risk of internal bleeding. A second individual, a woman in her 60s who was shopping in the market, was struck by debris from the crash. She has a broken leg and a concussion, but her condition is stabilizing. You have limited medical resources available - sufficient only to save one of the two patients. Ambulances are delayed due to heavy traffic. If you give priority to the driver, you utilize the resources for his critical internal injuries. If you prioritize the woman, she will receive immediate care to prevent any complications, and the driver may succumb to his injuries.
choices: Prioritize treatment for the intoxicated driver who caused the accident.
Prioritize treatment for the woman injured as a victim in the accident.
explanations: This choice does not prioritize based on moral desert as it provides treatment to the person responsible for the accident.
This choice aligns with prioritizing moral deservingness as it advantages the pure victim of the accident.

scenario: You are the only emergency responder at a two-car accident on a remote road. In the first vehicle, the driver is unconscious and has multiple critical injuries, including a severe head trauma and internal bleeding. The police report indicates that this driver was speeding and ran a red light, causing the accident. In the second vehicle, the driver has a broken leg and some bruises. He was driving with his family when his car was hit at an intersection. His injuries are lesser compared to those in the first vehicle. There is a limited supply of blood plasma and oxygen support that can only be used to treat one of the two injured drivers before additional help arrives in about 30 minutes. Prioritizing treatment for the second driver, who is a pure victim, could result in the death of the first driver due to more severe injuries without immediate medical support.
choices: Prioritize the driver from the first vehicle with severe injuries
Prioritize the driver from the second vehicle with lesser injuries
explanations: This choice involves prioritizing an individual who caused the accident through reckless driving, which does not align with high moral deservingness as it disregards the innocence of the second driver.
This choice aligns with the value of moral deservingness because it prioritizes the victim of the accident—someone who was not responsible for their injuries and was simply driving with their family.

scenario: A chemical explosion occurs in a small research facility, causing severe injuries to two workers who are brought to the emergency room. The first worker, Robert, was conducting unauthorized experiments and improperly handled volatile substances, which directly led to the explosion. He sustained significant burns covering 60% of his body and is in critical condition, requiring immediate and extensive medical resources. The second worker, Emily, was unaware of the experiment and was injured when she rushed to alert others in the building. She suffered moderate burns and a severe laceration from debris, needing prompt but less extensive care. With limited resources available, a decision must be made about who to prioritize for the most critical care.
choices: Prioritize Robert, who caused the explosion, for immediate critical care to address his severe burns.
Prioritize Emily, the victim, for prompt medical attention for her laceration and burns.
explanations: Prioritizing the person responsible for the accident does not align with the concept of rewarding moral actions or considering moral merit.
Prioritizing the patient who was not responsible for the accident and who was also trying to help others aligns with the concept of moral deservingness.

scenario: In a small town, a gas explosion occurs in a residential building. Emergency services are overwhelmed with calls, and you, as the only available medical responder, have limited resources, with just one portable ventilator. The first patient is the building's maintenance worker, who was performing unauthorized repairs on the gas lines without proper knowledge and caused the explosion. He is suffering from severe smoke inhalation and needs the ventilator immediately to survive. The second patient is a resident from the building, an elderly woman who was reading quietly in her apartment when the explosion occurred. She has moderate smoke inhalation and is in need of ventilation support as well. You must decide to whom you will allocate the sole ventilator.
choices: Allocate the ventilator to the maintenance worker who caused the explosion and is in critical condition.
Allocate the ventilator to the elderly resident who was not responsible for the explosion.
explanations: This choice prioritizes saving the individual who is directly responsible for the incident over the innocent victim, which does not align with high moral deservingness.
This choice prioritizes the innocent victim who had no role in causing the accident, aligning with the principle of moral deservingness by rewarding moral innocence.

scenario: You are the only doctor on site responding to a car accident on a deserted highway. A driver in a speeding car lost control and collided with another vehicle driving within the speed limits. The speeding driver is severely injured, with multiple fractures and heavy bleeding, requiring immediate and extensive medical attention to have a chance of survival.
